EntityDetailsItems.EntityDescription: 'Flore Pleno' is a vigorous herbaceous perennial to 90cm, with palmately divided dark green leaves and branched stems bearing long-lasting double, button-like white flowers 2cm in width
EntityDetailsItems.GenusDescription: Ranunculus can be annuals, biennials, evergreen or herbaceous perennials, with rhizomes, tubers or spreading by runners. The leaves are variable but often palmately lobed or dissected and the flowers usually bowl-shaped
EntityDetailsItems.SuggestedPlantUses: Cottage/Informal Garden, Flower borders and beds or Cut Flowers
EntityDetailsItems.Cultivation: Grow in humus-rich, fertile, moist or moist but well-drained soil in full or partial shade
EntityDetailsItems.DiseaseResistance: May be subject to powdery mildews in dry conditions
EntityDetailsItems.FoliageColour: Dark Green in Autumn, Spring and Summer

EntityDetailsItems.EntityDescription: 'Czakor' is a mat-forming perennial to around 20cm high with aromatic, deeply lobed, semi-evergreen foliage. Bright, magenta-pink flowers appear in late spring and early summer
EntityDetailsItems.GenusDescription: Geranium can be annuals, biennials and perennials, herbaceous or evergreen, with rounded, usually palmately lobed or divided leaves, and lax inflorescences of rounded, 5-petalled flowers
EntityDetailsItems.SuggestedPlantUses: Cottage/Informal Garden, Flower borders and beds, Ground Cover, Underplanting of Roses and Shrubs, Low Maintenance or Drought Resistant
EntityDetailsItems.Sunlight: Full Sun, Partial Shade, Full Shade
EntityDetailsItems.Cultivation: Useful as it is one of the few plants that can tolerate dry shade. Will grow in any, moderately fertile soil apart from waterlogged soils. Full sun or any type of shade
EntityDetailsItems.PestResistance: May get vine weevil, capsid bug and sawflies
EntityDetailsItems.DiseaseResistance: May be affected by a downy mildew and powdery mildews
EntityDetailsItems.Pruning: Remove flowered stems and old leaves to encourage the production of fresh leaves and flowers
EntityDetailsItems.Propagation: Propagate by division in spring or propagate by basal cuttings in early to mid spring and root with bottom heat
EntityDetailsItems.FoliageColour:
Bronze and Green in Autumn
Green in Spring, Summer and Winter

EntityDetailsItems.EntityDescription: 'Zounds' makes a compact mound of puckered, broadly ovate, golden yellow leaves to 25cm long, with very pale purple flowers in mid summer
EntityDetailsItems.GenusDescription: Hosta are clump-forming herbaceous perennials with simple, ovate or lance-shaped leaves, often attractively coloured or variegated, and erect racemes of nodding, funnel or bell-shaped flowers in early summer
EntityDetailsItems.SuggestedPlantUses: City/Courtyard Gardens, Coastal, Cottage/Informal Garden, Flower borders and beds, Ground Cover or Underplanting of Roses and Shrubs
EntityDetailsItems.Cultivation: Grow in fertile, moist but well-drained soil with shelter from cold, dry winds. Best in slightly acid or neutral soils; it will grow in alkaline soils if enriched but shallow, chalky soils can cause leaves to yellow. Partial shade is best but it can tolerate some sun if the soil is kept moist. Mulch in spring
EntityDetailsItems.PestResistance: May be attacked by slugs, snails and vine weevil
EntityDetailsItems.Propagation: Propagate by division in late summer or early spring

EntityDetailsItems.EntityDescription: B. maxima is an erect annual grass to 60cm, forming a tuft of flat, linear leaves, with panicles of large, flat, ovate, pale yellow spikelets which dangle from slender branches
EntityDetailsItems.GenusDescription: Briza can be annual or perennial grasses forming dense tufts of linear leaves, with long-lasting, open panicles of nodding spikelets on slender branches; useful for dried flower arrangement
EntityDetailsItems.SuggestedPlantUses: City/Courtyard Gardens, Cottage/Informal Garden, Flower borders and beds, Cut Flowers or Low Maintenance
EntityDetailsItems.Cultivation: Easy to grow in most well-drained fertile soils in a sunny position
EntityDetailsItems.Propagation: Propagate by seed, sown in situ in spring or autumn

EntityDetailsItems.EntityDescription: Violacea Group are dwarf perennial bulbs, to 15cm tall, with narrow grey-green leaves. Flowers, pink-purple with a yellow base, appear in late spring
EntityDetailsItems.GenusDescription: Tulipa are bulbous perennials with characteristic flowers, in a wide range of colours, in spring
EntityDetailsItems.SuggestedPlantUses: City/Courtyard Gardens, Cottage/Informal Garden, Flower borders and beds, Patio/Container Plants, Rock Garden or Wildflower meadow
EntityDetailsItems.Cultivation: Plant 10-15cm deep in fertile, well-drained soil in full sun, protect from excessive wet and shelter from strong winds, see tulip cultivation
EntityDetailsItems.PestResistance: Can be damaged by slugs, aphids and stem and bulb eelworm, squirrels may eat bulbs
EntityDetailsItems.DiseaseResistance: May be subject to tulip fire, tulip viruses and bulb rots
EntityDetailsItems.Toxicity: All parts may cause severe discomfort following ingestion; may cause an allergic skin reaction
EntityDetailsItems.Propagation: Propagate by lifting and separating offsets; see bulb propagation
EntityDetailsItems.Flower: Purple, Yellow and Dark Pink in Spring
EntityDetailsItems.FoliageColour: Pale Green and Pale Grey/Silver in Spring

EntityDetailsItems.EntityDescription: T. vvedenskyi is a perennial bulb to 40cm tall with narrow, wavy-edged, grey-green, often prostrate, leaves. The red to orange-red flowers reach up to 10.5cm long, with each petal marked yellow at the base
EntityDetailsItems.GenusDescription: Tulipa are bulbous perennials with characteristic flowers, in a wide range of colours, in spring
EntityDetailsItems.SuggestedPlantUses: Patio/Container Plants, Gravel Garden, Rock Garden, City/Courtyard Gardens or Cottage/Informal Garden
EntityDetailsItems.Cultivation: Needs a warm, sunny position with sharp drainage and protection from excessive wet, summer or winter. See tulip cultivation
EntityDetailsItems.PestResistance: Stem and bulb eelworm and slugs may be a problem
EntityDetailsItems.DiseaseResistance: May be subject to tulip fire and bulb rots
EntityDetailsItems.Toxicity: Ingestion may cause severe discomfort; may cause skin allergy
EntityDetailsItems.Propagation: Propagate by lifting and separating offsets
EntityDetailsItems.Flower: Red, Yellow and Dark Orange in Spring

EntityDetailsItems.EntityDescription: 'Irene Toyon' is a bushy plant to 45cm, with unzoned leaves and semi-double, vivid crimson-scarlet flowers
EntityDetailsItems.GenusDescription: Pelargonium can be perennials, sub-shrubs or shrubs, sometimes succulent and mostly evergreen, with palmately lobed or pinnately divided leaves and clusters of slightly irregular, 5-petalled flowers
EntityDetailsItems.Cultivation: Grow in fertile well-drained soil in full sun or partial shade. Remove spent flowers. To overwinter, grow small plants in late summer from cuttings or cut back old plants by one third and lift for storage in frost-free place to repot in spring when growth resumes
EntityDetailsItems.PestResistance: vine weevil, leafhoppers, caterpillars, thrips, fungus gnats and aphids can be troublesome. aphids are generally more problematic on over-wintered plants
EntityDetailsItems.DiseaseResistance: Foot and root rots can be a problem in wet soils. In wet conditions grey moulds are often troublesome. A virus can often be a problem where cultivars are maintained by cuttings. Pelargonium rust can be damaging to zonal pelargoniums and associated hybrids
EntityDetailsItems.Propagation: Take softwood cuttings in summer and overwinter plants in frost free conditions or take softwood cuttings in spring
EntityDetailsItems.FoliageColour: Green in Autumn, Spring, Summer and Winter
EntityDetailsItems.HortGroupDescription: Zonal pelargoniums are bushy evergreen perennials with fleshy stems, rounded, palmately lobed leaves often zoned with maroon, and single or double flowers in shades of purple, red, pink, orange and white, from early to late summer

EntityDetailsItems.AcceptedBotanicalName: Argyranthemum LaRita White Beauty 'Kleaf07028' (LaRita Series) AGM
EntityDetailsItems.EntityDescription: LaRita White Beauty forms a mound to 50 x 60 cm with silvery glaucous foliage and classic white-rayed, yellow-centred flowers to 4.5cm
EntityDetailsItems.GenusDescription: Argyranthemum are evergreen woody-based perennials or sub-shrubs, with simple or pinnately dissected leaves and white, yellow or pink, daisy-like flower-heads from late spring to autumn
EntityDetailsItems.SuggestedPlantUses: City/Courtyard Gardens, Coastal, Flower borders and beds, Patio/Container Plants, Mediterranean Climate Plants or Wall-side Borders
EntityDetailsItems.Cultivation: Grow in moderately fertile, well-drained soil in full sun. Deadhead regularly to prolong flowering and pinch growing tips to keep compact. Mulching may protect rootstock from frost, and helps to conserve water. Water in prolonged dry spells
EntityDetailsItems.PestResistance: Leaf miners may be a problem
EntityDetailsItems.DiseaseResistance: Crown gall is an occasional problem
EntityDetailsItems.Propagation: Root softwood cuttings in spring, and semi-hardwood cuttings of non-flowering shoots at other times
EntityDetailsItems.Flower: White and Yellow in Autumn, Spring and Summer
EntityDetailsItems.FoliageColour: Blue, Green and Grey/Silver in Autumn, Spring, Summer and Winter

EntityDetailsItems.EntityDescription: 'Marlo' is a bushy, upright, deciduous shrub with five- to seven-lobed palmate leaves. These are deep green, greyish towards the centre, with a broad, irregular, cream to pink margin turning deep pink in spring and autumn
EntityDetailsItems.GenusDescription: Acer can be deciduous trees or large shrubs with paired, often palmately-lobed leaves and small flowers followed by characteristic winged fruits. Many have fine autumn colour, and some have ornamental stems
EntityDetailsItems.SuggestedPlantUses: City/Courtyard Gardens, Cottage/Informal Garden, Low Maintenance, Flower borders and beds or Patio/Container Plants
EntityDetailsItems.Cultivation: Grow in moist, humus-rich, well-drained, acid to neutral soil. Hot dry air, cold wind and late frost may cause leaf scorching. Mulch in autumn to protect shallow roots from cold and drying out
EntityDetailsItems.PestResistance: Aphids and scale insects may be a problem
EntityDetailsItems.DiseaseResistance: Coral spot and verticillium wilt may be a problem
EntityDetailsItems.FoliageColour: Cream, Green, Pink and Variegated in Autumn, Spring and Summer

EntityDetailsItems.EntityDescription: 'Taplow Blue' is a robust, upright herbaceous perennial, with divided, prickly dark green leaves whitish beneath. Rounded, steel-blue flower heads on branched, leafy stems
EntityDetailsItems.GenusDescription: Echinops can be annuals, biennials or perennials with simple or pinnately lobed, spiny leaves and spherical blue or whitish flower-heads
EntityDetailsItems.SuggestedPlantUses: Cottage/Informal Garden, Flower borders and beds, Cut Flowers, Wildlife Gardens, Gravel Garden or Low Maintenance
EntityDetailsItems.Cultivation: Best in poor, well-drained soil in full sun but will tolerate most soils in full sun and can tolerate partial shade
EntityDetailsItems.Propagation: Propagate by seed sown in seed bed in mid spring. Propagate by division in spring or autumn. Propagate by root cuttings in winter
EntityDetailsItems.FoliageColour: Dark Green in Autumn, Spring and Summer
